pros: Heritage has the best internship program in DC. Period. You will work with some of the smartest people in policy, and they will make sure you are educated on all key issues in Washington. Heritage has a great mentorship program that pairs you up with someone relatively high up with similar background (I was paired with the head of one of the departments). Almost anyone who works there would be happy to get coffee with you if you reach out to them. The schedule is relatively relaxed, so you can take advantage of your time in DC; I had the chance to go to talks at Heritage and other thinktanks, take a tour of the Supreme Court, and so many more things. Not to mention the free Chick-Fil-a once a week in addition to other free food. If you have the opportunity to work this internship, do not miss it!
cons: Intern work can ebb and flow, and work varies across departments. While I found a way to fill in every hour of each day, others who didn't take as much initiative would sometimes be stuck twiddling their thumbs. If you work there, capitalize on free time if you have the chance.

pros:
+ Interesting people
+ Important work on fascinating issues--a great place to *get* experience
+ Opportunities to meet great thinkers
+ Great offices / location (if a bit cramped for those lower on the totem pole)
cons:
- Very stove-piped and stratified organization (this was before Jim DeMint took over, and I think he was a great choice).  The departments (of necessity) focus on their own areas of expertise, and don't necessarily interact that much.
- Some of the long-time career people that have been there awhile know how to protect their turf and their tenure better than they know how to make an impact
- Very conventional/establishment mindset, on the whole, compared to AEI (American Enterprise Institute), Cato Institute, and some of the smaller, more focused conservative think-tanks in town that push the envelope.

review_title: Hard to tell if staff are truly appreciated....
pros: There are a lot of great people scattered throughout the organization and passion for conservative causes ran high throughout the building. Being one of the largest think tanks out there, you'll get great exposure that you can bring to any other non-profit organization or career opportunity. High prestige factor and a business formal work environment if that is what you're looking for.
cons: Accounting deadlines were some of the most unreasonable, unrealistic I've seen in corporate accounting. Supposedly this varied by department but my work life balance was downright poor and overtime was frequent and expected. Salary was below market for DC, below market for accounting industry, below market for a large non-profit. Some of the company HR policies were poor and outdated, showed lack of appreciation for staff. Office layouts were also poor.

job_title: Health Policy Graduate Fellow in Washington, DC
pros: You know that your contributions will be used and impact policy.
cons: Sometimes you don't agree with the policies you are writing about. There is a particular agenda that must be supported if it is to be published by the Heritage Foundation and occasionally your own ideologies might not coincide with that agenda. You don't always get to choose the topics you would like to research and write about and it is nearly impossible to agree with a position entirely across the board. Also, the editing department sometimes makes drastic changes to your work and it might be difficult to be proud of your final publications because of the changes they have made.

review_title: Fairly Stodgy Foundation with Good People
pros: Fairly flexible work hours. No one here is pulling 80 hour weeks (despite what they may claim). Fairly good benefits and somewhat defined pathway to advancement.
cons: The corporate environment and information flow is the opposite of open. As a political organization, playing on the "right team" is more important than being "right," and this bleeds from ideology into office politics. Could use some updating, as the mode of management is straight from a 1982 MBA. There's a ton of churn of talent out after 1-4 years, as longevity and politicking are the only routes up the pyramid.

review_title: One of the Best Think Tanks in the Nation
pros: The best part of being an Intern at Heritage is that you get to do meaningful work (not your typical coffee runs like most interns on the hill). I was one of 60 interns in our "class" and they are some of my best friends I've ever had. This Foundation turns out some of the best and brightest-truly a completely different caliber.
cons: Your articles and blogs will not publish if they are at all misaligned with the foundation. It's best to keep personal opinions to yourself, but overall a wonderful place to work.

review_title: Best Place I have Ever Worked! Even as a Field Worker
pros: Friendly People who geuniely are kind and care about each other, Great Mission and Work if you agree with their policy views, lots on interesting chance to meet and interact with policy influencers, take good care of their people ie. free coffee machines, free events with free food, easy access via metro or car, education reimbursement in some departments,  well known and gain respect for working their, family/personal life is respected (yes long hours can happen but respect needs at home as long as you respect work time), the office space is amazing, pay raise every year i was with the organization, intern program is one of the best in DC, hard work and diligence can be rewarded, excellent benefits
cons: Re-reimbursement can take a while and no company credit cards but good at paying back it's people, long hours, blow back in the media and can be tough outside of the DC area to find work post experience  there,  field and DC staff can be a bit disconnected by they try REALLY hard to make this work, lazy workers don't last long here, sometimes to traditional and conservative (took some getting used too but it was all about respect), low pay but fair b/c of extras,

review_title: Heritage Foundation offers great introduction to DC
pros: As an intern for the Heritage Foundation, you're expected to substantively contribute to the work of senior analysts, but don't worry - there is plenty of mentoring and guidance along the way. The fact that its a paid internship in DC doesn't hurt, either.
cons: Sometimes the aforementioned guidance and direction can feel like hand-holding - While more work than other DC internships offer, sometimes the work load can feel very "watered down."

pros: As an intern, I basically got to work as a research assistant to two supervisors so I gained extremely valuable work experience. The lectures for the internship program were great and gave a thorough explanation of conservative values. Also, nothing beats getting a paid internship in D.C. because this exists practically nowhere else.
cons: The only con would be that interns only heard one side of the story. In lectures, presentations, events, etc. they'd only talk about the conservative point of view. I think it would help strengthen the conservative "argument" if they would present the liberal side, too.

pros: Wonderful people who care about work and personal life balance. I would recommend this organization to anyone who wants to work hard with people who will challenge you and push you to your highest professional potential.
cons: This is a not for profit environment which means that over time is not paid. Initial paid time off is not as high as others.There are a lot of great events but not always enough time in the day to get work done and attend.

review_title: Zero Diversity, except the mailroom and the cleaning crew
pros: My salary was on the higher end of what they normally pay.  For the most part the people were nice, despite their biases.  Beautiful workplace with 5 star accommodations and platinum perks.
cons: There is NO diversity.  African Americans and Hispanics are virtually non existent.  African Americans make up the mail room and Hispanics make up the cleaning crew.  No person of color in a leadership role.

pros: Worked with some of the most dynamic and interesting thinkers in Washington DC. Also a major plus are the constant lectures and book talks.
cons: Very hard to get to know people outside of one's individual department. And when relationships are formed, they are hard to keep up; you may not see a particular person for weeks at a time.

review_title: A great place for committed conservatives
pros:
Heritage is a great place for those looking to help further the conservative movement. It is very purpose driven -- at all times -- and values those who want to advance the cause.

In terms of work environment, it's very family friendly with normal hours in a city where that can be rare --- folks go home at 5:00, and they leave their work behind.
cons: There is some challenge with career advancement at Heritage, mostly due to the fact that people in higher positions of management typically don't leave.

pros: The Heritage Foundation cares about its employees at all levels, even interns. As far as the internship program goes, it is the best in DC by far. It pays AND they feed you about 3-4 times a week for lunch. There are always events to go to for networking or educational purposes. The internship program takes the class of about 60 on trips and is extremely organized. I could go on about how great it is!
cons: Really have no cons for THF.

pros: They give you free lunch practically every day. The people are so nice and the work environment is fast paced. They teach you about conservatism and how to defend it!
cons: I am not sure if I had a real negative experience while I was there. However, I wouldn't ever work for their events team again if I had a choice.

pros: Internship was pretty good, lots of great people to meet, networking opportunities, pay (unlike most internships in DC), and subsidized housing right next door.
cons: The research you do is pretty low quality. Most of it is just going through and digesting reports and news articles for your bosses and there's a lot of downtime. They don't teach you any research skills or data analysis which is disappointing.

pros: Heritage is the premiere think tank in Washington, DC. It is inspiring to be surrounded by some of the greatest minds and thought leaders in the world. The organization is committed to excellence in all departments and at all levels. A truly top-notch organization.
cons: At some times Heritage can be a touch bureaucratic, but that didn't bother me. They have solid procedures and policies that guide all operations.
